thread.title: Minutemen by the numbers: UMass defense hits new low with 725 yards allowed vs. Bowling Green
thread.title_full: Minutemen by the numbers: UMass defense hits new low with 725 yards allowed vs. Bowling Green

author: Daniel Malone | Special to MassLive
title: Minutemen by the numbers: UMass defense hits new low with 725 yards allowed vs. Bowling Green
text:
BOWLING GREEN, Ohio â€“ Here's a look behind some interesting and important numbers from the University of Massachusetts football team's 62-38 loss at Bowling Green Saturday. 725: Bowling Green's offensive yards 
The Falcons have been pretty potent on offense under coach Dino Babers, but never more so than Saturday. BG's total yardage was the most since Babers took over prior to the 2014 season. 5: Touchdown passes for Matt Johnson 
His five scores went to five different players: Ronnie Moore (71 yards), Roger Lewis (68 yards), Ryan Burbrink (40 yards), Travis Green (12 yards), Derek Lee (two yards). 30: UMass rushing yards 
Freshman Marquis Young led the team with 35 net yards (he fumbled, too). That five-yard difference should give you a good idea on how putrid the rushing attack was otherwise. 56: Pass attempts for Blake Frohnapfel 
It was the second time this season Frohnapfel has been asked to throw the ball more than 50 times and the sixth time overall. He's averaging 45.4/game this season, good for third-most in the nation. 91: Bowling Green offensive plays 
"Falcon fast" was on display again Saturday. BG is now averaging 89.5 snaps per game, behind only Tulsa (94.6) and West Virginia (90.5). Hard to defend on tired legs if you're UMass. 37:17: Bowling Green's time of possession 
With the Minutemen holding the ball for just 22:30, all those BG plays translated into a massive advantage in TOP. 100.0: Bowling Green's success rate in the red zone 
Not only did the Falcons move the ball with ease, but when they got done near the end zone, they capitalized every time. With four touchdowns and two field goals, BG went 6 for 6 in the red zone. 13: Receptions for Tajae Sharpe 
The senior wideout now has 58 catches, putting him on pace 139 this season. That would, uh, shatter the previous UMass record of 92.
